Micro-/mesopores confined ultrasmall Cu nanoparticles in SBA-15 as a highly efficient and robust catalyst for furfural hydrogenation to furfuryl alcohol Shuo Chen Investigation Writing – original draft a Priscilla M. de Souza Investigation a Carmen Ciotonea Investigation a b Maya Marinova Investigation b Franck Dumeignil a Sébastien Royer Funding acquisition a ⁎ Robert Wojcieszak Funding acquisition a ⁎ a Univ. The main difficulty in the liquid phase furfural hydrogenation process is the control of the selectivity to the target product among the possible ones. When copper catalysts are used, they often suffer from low stability in liquid medium. Herein, we report a general preparation method based on glycine-assisted in situ autocombustion to synthesize Cu supported catalysts. This method could lead to highly active, selective and stable catalysts in the liquid phase furfural hydrogenation. The resulting 10Cu-SBA-GLY catalyst (10 wt% Cu on SBA-15) could achieve a complete conversion of furfural to furfuryl alcohol under mild reaction conditions. Further, neither Cu leaching nor Cu NPs sintering were observed during the 5-run recycling tests, and the loss of conversion and selectivity stays below 3%. Such exceptional features make these Cu-SBA-GLY catalysts potential for the industrial applications not only in furfural hydrogenation but also in other hydroconversion processes. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Furfural hydrogenation Furfuryl alcohol Copper SBA-15 Confining effect 1 Introduction Nowadays, the selective production of value-added chemicals from sustainable biomass resources is highly sought for [1]. Due to its multifunctional nature (containing a furan ring and a pending aldehyde group), furfural (FF) is considered as one of the most important platform molecules bridging biomass resources and the biorefinery industry [2,3]. A wide range of high value derivatives such as furfuryl alcohol (FFA), tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol, 2-methylfuran, tetrahydrofuran, furan, pentane, and cyclopentanone can be produced from FF, which are widely used in the production of plastic, medicine, fertilizer, and fuel additives [4]. FFA is the most important FF-derived product to date, which is widely used as a raw material for the production of fine chemicals and synthetic fibers, rubbers and corrosion resistant glass fibers [5–7]. FF is transformed to FFA through the selective hydrogenation of the CO bond. FF being a multifunctional compound, one challenge for this catalytic transformation is to control the selectivity toward FFA formation: other secondary reactions, namely, hydrogenolysis, ring hydrogenation and ring opening can occur [8]. Up to now, many processes have been developed for FFA production from FF, including the use of noble metal-based catalysts and non-noble metal-based catalysts, either in gas phase or in liquid phase [1,9–14]. The commercial catalyst system for FFA production from FF involves copper chromite (CuCr2O4) [15]. However, the toxicity of copper chromite has caused environmental concerns and thus motivated the development of Cr-free catalysts [16]. It has been settled that noble metal (e.g., Pt, Pd, and Ir) - based catalysts doped with oxophilic additives (e.g., Cu, Sn and Re) could afford high catalytic performances [6,17,18]. For example, a 98.6% yield of FFA over Pd-Cu/MgO, a 98% yield over Pt3Sn/SnO2/rGO, and a 99% yield over Ir-ReOx/SiO2 have been reported [19–21]. However, noble metal-based catalysts suffer from high and fluctuating costs. It is necessary to develop alternative non-noble metal (e.g., Ni, Co, Fe, Cu) - based Cr-free catalysts. Compared to other metals, Cu-based catalysts are generally featured by: (i) the selective hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis of the pendant groups, due to the preferential tilted η1-(O) adsorption mode with the oxygen of the -CHO group binding to Cu surface and the furan ring repulsed away; (ii) a relatively low activity for H2 activation [22–27]. The former enables Cu to minimize side transformations of FF while the latter usually restricts its hydrogenation activity and makes it challenging to develop highly efficient Cu-based catalysts. In order to achieve high hydrogenation reactivities, strategies like adding a second metal and/or using a promoting catalyst support (e.g., TiO2, ZnO, MgO, etc.) have been widely attempted. For instance, high yields of FFA (> 80%) were obtained with bimetallic Cu-based catalysts (e.g., CuCe/kerolitic clay, CuCo/γ-Al2O3, CuCo/SBA-15) and Cu-doped metal oxide catalysts (e.g.,CuAl2O4, CuZnAl, CuMgAl) [17,28–36]. However, this strategy unavoidably leads to an increase in the cost and complexity of the Cu-based catalysts, especially when noble metals are added, and thus limits its practical application prospects [37]. The development of efficient monometallic Cu-based catalysts is thus highly sought for. Another obstacle that has to be dealt with Cu-based catalysts results from poor stability [27,38]. On one hand, given the instability of copper nanoparticles (NPs) under thermal conditions during catalyst synthesis, it is very challenging to achieve finely-dispersed Cu NPs: very often the high temperature treatments give rise to large Cu NPs with low active surface [39–42]. This is especially the case with Cu/SiO2, which has been considered as one of the most promising industrially applicable catalyst, due to the high mobility of copper on the surface of SiO2 [43]. On the other hand, in the real catalysis environment, Cu NPs often suffer from particle sintering. This often results in rapid loss of catalytic activity which is one of the main reasons for copper catalyst deactivation [44–46]. The preparation of finely dispersed monometallic Cu-based catalysts which can resist thermal instability under catalytic conditions appears to be still challenging at present. SBA-15, as one of the most popular ordered mesoporous silica materials, has attracted special attention due to its high thermal stability, highly ordered and uniform structure, high specific surface area, easily controllable channel size and tunable microporosity [43,47,48]. The confining of the active phase inside the micro-/mesoporosity of SBA-15 would ensure the fine dispersion and sintering resistance of the nanostructured particles [49–52]. The size of the meso-channels (2–30 nm) could mitigate the diffusion barrier for reactants and products and allow their easy access to the active phase [53,54]. As a result, the copper@SBA-15 composite would behave as an ideal reactor. To the best of our knowledge, very few work concerning the use of SBA-15 as a support for monometallic copper has been reported so far. Only one study investigated such a system for furfural hydrogenation but the Cu/SBA-15 catalyst lost its activity rapidly [55]. In order to stabilize Cu NPs inside the micro-/mesopores of SBA-15, it requires to carefully select the catalyst preparation method. When the base-assisted deposition precipitation method is used, finely dispersed Cu NPs can be formed but the resulting catalysts face the risk of instability owing to degradation of SBA-15 channel structure by the basic solution during catalyst synthesis [56]. The classical impregnation method can retain the ordered structure of SBA-15 but often results in aggregation of Cu NPs due to the deposition of the metal precursors outside the support body during drying [57]. In order to take advantage of the confinement effects of the micro-/mesopores of SBA-15, one option involves the glycine assisted autocombustion process. The combustion reaction occurs exothermically after the self-ignition of a glycine-metal nitrates mixture inside the channels of SBA-15 [58]. This strategy has been designed to avoid the redistribution of the metal nitrates, facilitate the incorporating of the resulting ultrasmall NPs (< 5 nm) inside the support matrix and thus enhance the catalytic reactivities [54,58]. However, until now this strategy has been scarcely applied for Cu/SBA-15 synthesis, and the only reaction dealt with is the CWPO of phenol reaction [54]. Herein, this work integrates the positive effects of glycine assisted autocombustion procedure with the advantage of confining the active copper phase inside the micro-/mesopores of SBA-15, which for the first time achieved a highly efficient and robust monometallic Cu/SBA-15 catalyst (Cu-SBA-GLY) for the selective reduction of FF to FFA. The morphological, structural and textural features of the fresh, reduced and used catalysts have been evaluated by using multiple techniques. The active phase in the form of highly dispersed nanoparticles have been stabilized inside the micro-/mesopores of SBA-15, which led to a considerable enhancement of the catalytic performance as compared to the one prepared by the deposition precipitation method (Cu-SBA-DP) and the most significant Cu-based catalysts reported in literature. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All chemicals required to prepare the mesoporous SBA-15 silica support and the transition metal-containing materials were used as purchased: tetraethylorthosilicate (Si(OC2H5)4, TEOS, 98 wt%, Sigma-Aldrich), non-ionic triblock copolymer Pluronic P123 (poly(ethylene oxide)-block-poly(propylene oxide)-blockpoly(ethylene oxide)-block, PEO20PPO70PEO20, molecular weight of 5800 g/mol, BASF Corp.), hydrochloric acid (HCl, 37 wt%, Sigma-Aldrich), copper (II) nitrate hexahydrated (Cu(NO3)2·6H2O, 98 wt%, Sigma-Aldrich), glycine (> 99.0 wt%, Sigma-Aldrich, ACS reagent). 2.2 Catalysts preparation The SBA-15 support was synthesized via the hydrothermal method: 4.00 g Pluronic P123 were added to 150 mL of HCl solution (1.6 M), and stirred at 40 °C for 6 h. 8.5 g of TEOS was added and stirred for 24 h, followed by a hydrothermal treatment at 100 °C for 48 h. The solid was thereafter filtered, washed, dried at 80 °C for 12 h and calcined at 550 °C for 6 h. The 5Cu-SBA-GLY, 10Cu-SBA-GLY, 20Cu-SBA-GLY, 10Cu-SiO2-GLY and 10Cu-MCM-41-GLY samples were prepared using glycine assisted in situ autocombustion method. For the preparation of 1 g of 5 wt% Cu/SBA-15 (5Cu-SBA-GLY), 50 mL of a copper nitrate aqueous solution (0.016 mmol mL−1; Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O, 98%, Sigma-Aldrich) and 50 mL of a glycine aqueous solution (0.149 mmol mL−1; NH2CH2COOH, 99%, Sigma-Aldrich) were mixed together and stirring for 12 h at room temperature. The resulting solution was added dropwisely to 0.95 g of SBA-15 powder, and then aged for 12 h. The blue gel was heated at 100 °C until water was evaporated. A white solid was obtained and combusted at 300 °C for 30 min in an open vessel in an oven under static air conditions. The combusted sample was collected at room temperature and then calcined at 500 °C for 6 h under static air conditions with a ramp of 1 °C/min. The 10Cu-SBA-DP sample was prepared using deposition precipitation method. 0.9 g SBA-15 was added in 70 mL distilled water. 35 mL of copper nitrate aqueous solution (0.046 mmol mL−1) was added. The temperature was increased to 90 °C. Then, 35 mL of urea solution (0.534 mmol mL−1) with the mass ratio of urea/copper nitrate equaling to 3 was added to the slurry solution. After 24 h, the precipitates was filtered, washed dried at 80 °C overnight and then calcined at 500 °C for 6 h. 2.3 Sample characterization PXRD were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer in Bragg-Brentano configuration, with a Cu Kα radiation (γ = 1.54184 Å). N2 physisorption experiments were performed at − 196 °C, on a Micromeritics Tristar II Plus instrument. Textural properties were calculated from the adsorption/desorption isotherms by using Tristar II software version 1.55. HRTEM analysis was performed on a JEOL 2100 UHR, operated at 200 kV with a LaB6 source and equipped with a Gatan 832 CCD camera. STEM was conducted wth TITAN Themis 300S/TEM. The high angle annular dark field (HAADF) images were collected at angles between 50 and 200 mrad. TPR was performed on an Autochem analyzer (Micromeritics) equipped with a quartz U-shaped microreactor. The samples were heated up to 900 °C, with a temperature ramp of 10 °C/min. XPS were performed on an AXIS Ultra DLD Kratos spectrometer equipped with a monochromatized aluminium source (Al Kα = 1486.7 eV) and a charge compensation gun. The spectra were obtained after the samples were purged at room temperature under vacuum. ICP-AES were performed using sequential scanning inductively coupled plasma with an optical emission spectrometer (Perkin Elmer Optima 2000 DV). 2.4 Catalytic test Catalytic tests were performed on a batch reaction system commercialized by Parr Company. Before the test, the catalyst was reduced at 250 °C for 2 h with a temperature ramp of 10 °C/min under 5 vol% H2 in Ar flow (50 mL/min). First, 20 mL of a furfural solution in cyclopentyl methyl ether- CPME (FF/Cu = 50, 100 or 300) were added to the reactor together with 100 mg of reduced catalyst. The reactor was pressurized with 5 bar of hydrogen before turning the heating on. Finally, when the desired temperature (150 °C) was reached, the stirring was turned on and the reactor was then sealed and charged with H2 (20 bar). The reaction time was initiated after stirring started (600 rpm). Finally, the system was cooled to room temperature, and the liquid products were analyzed using a GC (Shimadzu GC 2010 PLUS, Kyoto, Japan) equipped with a ZB-WAX Plus column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 m) and a FID (flame ionization detector). GC-MS was used to ensure precision in the identification of the products. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization Fig. 1a and Fig. S1a show the low angle XRD patterns for the Cu-SBA-GLY catalysts series and the reference catalyst 10Cu-SBA-DP. For the Cu-SBA-GLY catalysts, three diffraction peaks indexed as (100), (110) and (200) planes between 0.5 and 5° are present, characteristic of the 2D hexagonal arrangement of cylindrical channels with long range regularity, indicating that the ordered mesopore structure of SBA-15 support is always preserved after the self-propagating combustion process [54]. Two additional phenomenon could also be observed: (i) an obvious shift of the peaks to higher angles as compared to the parent SBA-15 support, indicating a contraction of the cell parameters; (ii) the difference in attenuation of the diffraction peaks intensity, associated to the modification of the contrast density between the pores and the inorganic walls. Both are possibly caused by the incorporation of copper phase within the framework of the siliceous support [44,54–59]. For 10Cu-SBA-DP, a significant decrease in the diffraction intensity of (110) and (200) reflections occurs, suggesting a notable alteration of the ordered mesopore structure at long range and a poorly retained uniformity, which was caused by the partial dissolution of the siliceous SBA-15 in the alkaline solution during the deposition precipitation process [59–61]. Fig. 1b shows the high angle XRD patterns of the Cu-SBA-GLY catalysts. For 5Cu-SBA-GLY, the peaks at 35.5° and 38.7° characteristic of the monoclinic CuO phase (JCPDS file no 048-1548) is not detected, implying the crystal size below the detection limit (< 3 nm) or eventually, the remaining of copper oxide in an amorphous state [54]. When the copper loading increases to 10 wt% of Cu as for 10Cu-SBA-GLY, CuO reflections remain poorly defined and of week intensity. The low diffraction intensity does not allow calculating an average crystals size. More visible reflections are present for 20Cu-SBA-GLY, the average CuO crystal size of which, as calculated from the Scherrer equation, is 8.5 nm, approximately fitting the pore size of the SBA-15 support ( Table 1). Fig. 1c shows the high angle XRD patterns of 10Cu-SBA-GLY and 10Cu-SBA-DP which are before and after in situ reduction in 5 vol% H2/N2 atmosphere for 2 h. For 10Cu-SBA-DP, before reduction, there are no visible diffraction peaks but only baseline fluctuations at 30.8°, 35.0°, 57,5° and 62.4°, which correspond to the chrysocolla-type copper silicates, indicating the fine dispersion of the copper silicates [61]. After reduction at 250 °C, the diffractions of the metallic Cu at 43.3°, 50.4° and 74.1° (JCPDS file no 04-0836), appear in both 10Cu-SBA-GLY and 10Cu-SBA-DP. Notably, the average crystal size (based on Scherrer equation) of Cu NPs in 10Cu-SBA-DP obviously increased (< 3 nm vs. 5.9 nm, before and after reduction, respectively), indicating the instability and sintering of Cu NPs under thermal treatment conditions. In contrast, 10Cu-SBA-GLY, with significantly broad reflections formed after reduction (average size still difficult to calculate), exhibited only subtle change in crystal size and thus much higher resistance to sintering during the thermal treatment. In order to elucidate the chemical states of the Cu phase in 10Cu-SBA-GLY and 10Cu-SBA-DP after H2 reduction, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and the Cu LMM X-ray Auger Electron Spectroscopy (XAES) analysis were performed. As exhibited in Fig. 2a, the Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 peaks for both samples (freshly reduced in situ in the XPS analysis chamber) appear at 932.7 and 952.4 eV, respectively, which suggests that the Cu2+ species in both samples was reduced to the low valent copper species (i.e., Cu0 or Cu+) [62,63]. Fig. 2b presents the Cu LMM XAES spectrum. The kinetic energy of both reduced samples is 918.5 eV, suggesting that the copper species is Cu0 [64,65]. The nitrogen physisorption isotherms and pore size distributions of Cu-SBA-GLY and 10Cu-SBA-DP samples are presented in Fig. 3 and Fig. S2, and the textural parameters are gathered in Table 1. It can be observed that all Cu-SBA- GLY samples display a type IV isotherm with a H1-type hysteresis loop, which is typical of the mesoporous SBA-15 structure with a narrow pore size distribution of cylindrical pores [66]. Therefore, upon formation of the CuO phase after the glycine assisted autocombustion procedure, the organized pore structure of SBA-15 support is maintained as observed from XRD analysis. The main evolutions concerning different textural properties upon increase in Cu content up to 20 wt% could also be observed. First, the shift down along the y-axis with the increase in copper loading clearly indicates a decrease in pore volume, as summarized in Table 1 (−15%, −28%, −46% for 5Cu-SBA-GLY, 10Cu-SBA-GLY, 20Cu-SBA-GLY, respectively), which can be explained by the partial pore filling after introducing the CuO phase. Remarkably, an important decrease in the micropore volume (−40%, −60%, −60% for 5Cu-SBA-GLY, 5Cu-SBA-GLY, 2010Cu-SBA-GLY, respectively) is also measured between SBA-15 and the Cu-SBA-GLY samples, implying a significant quantity of CuO species also incorporated inside the micro porosity [67]. The specific surface area and the microporous surface area are found to decrease with increase in copper loading, but the average pore diameter is only slightly altered whatever the loading of the copper loading, which indicates that the formation of CuO phase indeed results in a redistribution of the pore opening size of the SBA-15 support, but the change is not that extensive and the pore blockage is prevented [68,69]. As for 10Cu-SBA-DP, a transformation of the hysteresis loop from H1 type of SBA-15 to H2 type-like implies the degraded regularity of the support structure, which is directly reflected by the pore size distribution curve as shown in Fig. S2. This is in agreement with the low angle XRD results. Fig. 4 shows the representative microscopy images of the Cu-SBA-GLY samples before reduction. It could be observed that: (i) the ordered SBA-15 structure with hexagonal arrays of pores is maintained whatever the Cu loading, confirming the results of low angle XRD and porosity analysis; (ii) in all samples, there is no external CuO aggregates outside the channels, CuO NPs being well confined inside the matrix of the support; (iii) the formation of ultra-small CuO NPs (size much lower than the support pore size, see in Table 1) highly dispersed into the silica walls for all loadings, highlighting the important role of the micropores in stabilizing the copper phase; (iv) the formation of mesopore-size-fitting CuO particles is hardly observed especially in low copper loading cases (5Cu-SBA-GLY and 10Cu-SBA-GLY), suggesting a lowest pore plugging as experimentally observed by N2-physisorption; increasing copper loading (20Cu-SBA-GLY) leads to an increase in the average particle size due to the increased quantity of pore plugging particles though the open pores with confined CuO NPs still dominate. These results indicate that the glycine assisted method enables obtaining finely dispersed CuO NPs (3.2 nm in average for 10Cu-SBA-GLY) incorporated inside the micro-/mesopores of SBA-15 while retaining the hexagonal structure of SBA-15 and efficiently avoiding pore blocking. In contrast, in the case of 10Cu-SBA-DP as shown in Fig. S3, the deposition precipitation method results in a significant alternation of the support structure though the dispersion of copper species is high: the hexagonal pore arrays disappear. This is consistent with the observation in the low angle XRD and N2-physisorption results. In order to further study the effect of the micro-/mesopore confining on the morphology evolution of the copper phase during the thermal treatment, the microscopy analysis of 10Cu-SBA-GLY and 10Cu-SBA-DP samples after reduction was performed and presented in Fig. 5. For 10Cu-SBA-GLY, it could be observed that the H2 reduction at 250 °C did neither cause obvious alternation of the support structure nor the formation of aggregated copper NPs or consequent particle growth. The fine Cu NPs with an average particle size of 3.1 nm are homogeneously dispersed inside the support channels with a majority incorporated inside the silica walls as could be easily observed in Fig. 5b and c. This confirms the absence of the sintering phenomenon and the high thermal stability of the confined copper phase, as previously suggested by the high angle XRD data. In contrast, 10Cu-SBA-DP experienced a notable morphology change during the H2 reduction process: the filamentous nanoparticles, which correspond to the chrysocolla-type copper silicates – the precursor of copper nanoparticles as observed in the calcined sample, disappear, and there is an obvious growth of Cu particle size, leading to an average particle size up to 5.6 nm (from hardly visible before reduction, see in Fig. S3). This indicates the thermal stability of the unconfined copper phase in 10Cu-SBA-DP markedly inferior to the confined copper particles in 10Cu-SBA-GLY. The reducibility of the Cu-SBA-GLY samples and 10Cu-SBA-DP was evaluated by H2-TPR, as shown in Fig. 6. The H2-TPR profiles expose only one main hydrogen consumption peak with the reduction temperature summit at 227 °C for 5Cu-SBA-GLY, 248 °C for 10Cu-SBA-GLY, 249 °C for 20Cu-SBA-GLY, and 245 °C for 10Cu-SBA-DP, respectively, which are in the typical range of reduction temperature of Cu2+ to Cu0 NPs with limited particle size (< 10 nm), and indicates no formation of external bulk CuO phases (reduction temperature higher than 300 °C) [70]. The reduction temperature of CuO NPs strongly depends on the particle size and dispersion, the increase of the reduction temperature with the copper loading implies a slight increase of the CuO particle size, which is consistent with the high angle XRD and TEM results [49,71]. The reduction degree of 5Cu-SBA-GLY, 10Cu-SBA-GLY, 20Cu-SBA-GLY and 10Cu-SBA-DP were calculated based on the Cu content and hydrogen consumption, giving 80%, 89%, 96%, and 82%, respectively (Table 1). The relatively lower reduction degree exhibited by less copper loaded Cu-SBA-GLY catalysts could be assigned to the existence of more isolated Cu2+ species which are more difficult to reduce than small CuO particles [72,73]. Whereas the low reduction degree exhibited by 10Cu-SBA-DP possibly results from the existence of CuOSi bonds from the precursor silicate phase which is supposed to hinder the complete reduction of Cu2+ [74]. 3.2 Catalytic performance The catalytic performance and selectivity to FFA for all the catalysts are presented in Fig. 7. It is generally admitted that the nature of the solvent strongly influences the selectivity of this reaction [74–77]. Isopropanol (IPA) is one of the mostly used solvent for FF conversion to FFA ( Table 2) [1]. But IPA may lead to forming secondary products (resulting in a decrease of the carbon balance) via catalytic transfer of hydrogen from the solvent [62,78]. We thus decided to perform the test in cyclopentyl methyl ether (CPME) which is a green solvent and also prevents the degradation of furfural even at 150 °C as shown on Fig. S5. It could be noted that under the selected reaction conditions (150 °C, 20 bar H2, 2 h in CPME), the FF conversion was less than 2% without catalyst or with the SBA-15 support alone. The reference 10Cu-SBA-DP catalyst failed full FF conversion. Instead, it afforded a FFA selectivity of 94% at a FF conversion of 72%. In contrast, 10Cu-SBA-GLY, which has the same copper loading, achieved an exclusive selectivity to FFA of 100% at complete FF conversion. According to previous studies, the well dispersed metallic Cu particles or a proper portion of Cu+ species combining with small metallic Cu NPs are responsible for the observed activity [39,45,55,71,79]. However, in our case Cu+ is not detected as confirmed by the XAES results. Therefore, the metallic Cu NPs are considered as the active sites. Based on the previously presented characterization results, 10Cu-SBA-GLY retains high dispersion of copper phase after reduction due to its high thermal stability, and its copper phase could be easily transformed to the metallic copper due to its high reducibility. In contrast, 10Cu-SBA-DP shows low dispersion of copper phase after reduction and relatively low reducibility. Hence, it is reasonable to expect 10Cu-SBA-GLY to expose more active metallic copper sites than 10-SBA-DP to the reactant during FF hydrogenation and thus obtain higher catalytic performance. The effect of the micro-/mesopore confined copper phase on FF conversion to FFA has been scarcely reported in literature so far. For this reason, the effect of copper content in SBA-15 from 5 wt%, to 20 wt% on the catalytic performance has been further investigated. From Fig. 7a, it can be noted that 5 wt% dispersed Cu NPs in SBA-15, or namely 5Cu-SBA-GLY, appears to be sufficient to achieve full FF conversion under the selected reaction conditions. However, 5Cu-SBA-GLY failed the exclusive formation of FFA, only giving a selectivity of 89%. The carbon loss here could be explained by the formation of polymerization product from FF, which is hardly detected [80–82]. When the copper loading was further increased to 10 wt% and 20 wt%, the carbon loss was avoided and a 100% yield of FFA was thus obtained, indicating the higher catalytic activity with higher Cu loading catalysts which could efficiently promote the partial hydrogenation of FF before its polymerization. As aforementioned, the high catalytic activity of the Cu-SBA-GLY samples could be assigned to the fine dispersion of the metallic copper phase, the high catalyst reducibility as well as the maintaining of the major pore opening, since these properties together could assure sufficient active copper sites inside the SBA-15 channels accessible to the reactant. In addition, over all the Cu-SBA-GLY samples, only FFA was detected as a product while the other hydrogenation products from FF, such as 2-methylfuran, 2-methyltetrahydrofuran and 1,2-pentanediol, were not observed under the reaction conditions applied here. This indicates the exclusive selectivity of the resulting Cu-SBA-GLY samples to the hydrogenation of the pendant aldehyde group of FF. Inspired by its excellent catalytic performance and relatively lower Cu content, 10Cu-SBA-GLY was chosen for the deeper study. We then studied the influence of the FF:Cu molar ratio, as presented in Fig. 7b, and observed that even for a high FF:Cu ratio up to 300, a high FFA yield of 90% could still be obtained after 2 h of reaction. This result suggests that 10Cu-SBA-GLY is highly potential for the selective conversion of concentrated FF solutions. In general, the reusability of a catalyst during operation is one of the key issues in the development of the material. In order to investigate this property, the stability of 10Cu-SBA-GLY catalyst was subsequently tested during a 5 recycling test. From Fig. 8 it can be noted that there is no loss of activity and selectivity after 5 consecutive runs, which eventually confirms the high stability of this catalyst. It is worth noting that the catalyst was not subjected to any treatment between the consecutive runs. The ICP-OES analysis of the reaction solution after tests demonstrates an absence of solubilized copper, confirming no leaching of copper species occurred or the content below the detection limit of the ICP-OES. This is an important fact, as the leaching of the active phase is one of the drawbacks often mentioned in literature when using copper catalysts in liquid phase reactions [1]. Vargas-Hernández and co-workers studied FF hydrogenation over a Cu/SBA-15 catalyst which was prepared through the incipient wetness impregnation method [55]. Though high catalytic activity was obtained, the optimized catalyst experienced a strong deactivation due to the carbon deposition. A recent work by Du et al. also reported the deactivation of a Cu/SiO2 catalyst caused by carbon deposition [62]. This is clearly not the case in our study, considering a carbon balance always higher than 98% during the recycling tests, which means the avoiding of massive formation of carbon/adsorbed intermediates that should have been detrimental to the catalytic activity. Besides, the porosity analysis of the spent catalyst exhibited similar porosity parameters (SBET 459 m2/g, Dp 8.7 nm, Vp 0.80 cm3/g) with the fresh catalyst, suggesting the retaining of the mesoporous porosity after the recycling. In addition, the absence of significant sintering and mesostructured degradation during recycling was confirmed by the microscopy analysis as presented in Fig. 9, which indicates that the glycine assisted method used in this study enabled avoiding the sintering of Cu NPs, allowing to stabilize small Cu NPs sizes in the micro-/mesopores under the real reaction environment [83]. The catalytic performances of Cu on different type of SiO2 were also compared. As shown in Table S1, 10Cu-MCM-41-GLY could afford a normalized reaction rate (rN) of 24.5 h−1 which is very close to that of 10Cu-SBA-GLY (25.0 h−1), indicating a similar FF hydrogenation activity of the two catalysts. However, 10Cu-MCM-41-GLY suffered from a low selectivity to FFA (0.8%) and a low carbon balance (18.1%), which was caused by severe FF polymerization during the reaction. The recycling test showed a significant activity loss (> 40%) of 10Cu-MCM-41-GLY due to the carbon deposits on the catalyst surface. 10Cu-SiO2-GLY (a commercial amorphous SiO2) exhibited relatively lower activity (rN = 12.9 h−1) than that of 10Cu-SBA-GLY and 10Cu-MCM-41-GLY, and lower FFA selectivity than that of 10Cu-SBA-GLY. 10Cu-SiO2-GLY experienced a gradual loss of activity during the recycling test (> 40% after 2 cycles). These results suggest that as compared to other SiO2 supports, SBA-15 shows high potential as a suitable support for the efficient conversion of FF to FFA. Table 2 summarizes the catalytic performances of the most significant catalyst systems reported in literature. As aforementioned, many attempts have been made so far to develop highly efficient Cr-free Cu-based catalysts at aspect of both hydrogenation reactivity and catalyst reusability. For example, the vapor-phase hydrogenation of FF in the previous studies have reported the high rN (the normalized reaction rate) of 1512 h−1 for Cu/SiO2 at 230 °C [84] and 262–2858 h−1 for Cu-MgO at 180 °C [85]. In liquid-phase FF hydrogenation, the rN of reported Cu-based catalysts could reach up to 36.4 h−1 with the promotion of Na additive: Na-Cu@TS-1 could provide such a rN at 110 °C [86]. However, this catalyst suffered from Na leaching and the resulting significant activity loss during the recycling tests. Cu/AC-SO3H and Cu/MCM-41 demonstrated high reusability – the catalysts resisted 5 consecutive cycles without obvious activity loss, but showed limited activity per metal site, giving a rN of 1.3 h−1 at 110 °C and 10.0 h−1 at 120 °C, respectively [87,88]. The other reported monometallic and bi-/multi-metallic Cu based catalysts also suffered from either low activity per metal site or limited catalyst stability, and for some catalyst systems from the both. In contrast, the 10Cu-SBA-GLY system fabricated in this work displayed a prominent improvement in both activity per metal site (rN = 25 h−1) and catalyst reusability, especially when compared with the other monometallic Cu-based catalysts. 10Cu-SBA-GLY is the only catalyst that can achieve high activity per metal site and at the same time presents high selectivity and reusability in liquid-phase FF hydrogenation. Moreover, neither extra metal except for Cu nor catalyst functionalization is required by this catalyst. These advantages make this catalyst highly potential for the practical applications in industry. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, we have outlined synthesis and characterization of the monometallic Cu/SBA-15 catalysts using a glycine assisted autocombustion route as well as a reference catalyst through the deposition precipitation method. Subsequent characterizations of the nanocatalysts clearly showed that the synthesis procedure is efficient in avoiding pore plugging and achieving nanometric copper particles well stabilized onto the silica surface of both micropores and mesopores, which was finally verified to contribute significantly to the copper phase stability during both in thermal treatments and in real catalysis environment. The resulting Cu/SBA-15 catalyst is highly active and selective in liquid phase hydrogenation of furfural toward the production of furfuryl alcohol. The use of cheap and available materials (Cu and SiO2) is very interesting from the industrial point of view. The excellent reusability of the catalyst as demonstrated during the recycling tests as well as its tolerance to highly concentrated furfural conditions, makes it a potential candidate for the industrial application, not only in furfural hydrogenation but also in other hydroconversion processes. coredata.dc:description: The main difficulty in the liquid phase furfural hydrogenation process is the control of the selectivity to the target product among the possible ones. When copper catalysts are used, they often suffer from low stability in liquid medium. Herein, we report a general preparation method based on glycine-assisted in situ autocombustion to synthesize Cu supported catalysts. This method could lead to highly active, selective and stable catalysts in the liquid phase furfural hydrogenation. The resulting 10Cu-SBA-GLY catalyst (10 wt% Cu on SBA-15) could achieve a complete conversion of furfural to furfuryl alcohol under mild reaction conditions. Further, neither Cu leaching nor Cu NPs sintering were observed during the 5-run recycling tests, and the loss of conversion and selectivity stays below 3%. Such exceptional features make these Cu-SBA-GLY catalysts potential for the industrial applications not only in furfural hydrogenation but also in other hydroconversion processes.
coredata.dc:title: Micro-/mesopores confined ultrasmall Cu nanoparticles in SBA-15 as a highly efficient and robust catalyst for furfural hydrogenation to furfuryl alcohol
